Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation2: A patient has a combination of unusual symptoms that are not immediately linked to a single known illness.
Story:
I stared at my phone, rereading Mia’s message: “Let’s pick a night for our date! I’m free all week.” I could almost hear her excitement, and I wanted to match it. We’d both been so busy lately, and I knew how much she valued our time together. But as I started to type a reply, my mind drifted back to the hospital. There was a patient—Mr. Lee—whose symptoms didn’t fit any textbook pattern. I’d spent hours reviewing his charts, running tests, and still, nothing made sense. The pressure to find an answer weighed on me; his family was counting on me, and so was he.

I felt torn. Mia deserved my attention, laughter, and presence. But Mr. Lee needed my focus, my expertise, and maybe even my late nights. I could feel the expectations pulling me in opposite directions—one toward love and connection, the other toward duty and responsibility. My heart ached as I realized I couldn’t give my best to both at the same time. My fingers hovered over my phone, caught between two worlds, unsure which one I’d have to let down.
